content: Unfortunately, both Snopes and Politifact have a heavy bias that really must be weighed before considering them trustworthy-by-default. I trust Snopes for most “urban legend” issues, but anyone who takes political statements and wants you to take them on authority that their interpretation is proof of something being “true”, “mostly true” or “mostly false”, or “pants-on-fire”, should be considered more-suspect-than-average, not more reliable. A “perfect fact-checker” would be crowdsourced, have fixed editorial standards (certain words or phrasing disallowed — explicitly including casting verdicts). The goal would be not simplifying the evaluation into a single, handy, pre-chosen judgment, but rather fully evaluating the possible interpretations of a given statement and collecting the precise, well-sourced, facts relevant to those interpretations. Truth-values are still ultimately going to come down to interpretation though, in most cases. In any case, I appreciate this article and the spirit of “detecting fake news”… I believe it is key to the long-term solution that gets us out of the negative situation we find ourselves in presently.
